articles.headline: France Investigates Lafarge Executives for Terrorist Financing
articles.snippet: One of France’s biggest companies faces claims it helped finance the Islamic State and several armed groups when it operated in Syria from 2012 to 2014.
articles.abstract: One of France’s biggest companies faces claims it helped finance the Islamic State and several armed groups when it operated in Syria from 2012 to 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The former chief executive of LafargeHolcim, the world’s largest cement maker, and five other top officials are being formally investigated as part of a government inquiry into whether the company helped finance the Islamic State militant group and other armed factions while operating a factory in Syria.

articles.headline: Environmentalists Ask: Is India’s Government Making Bad Air Worse?
articles.snippet: As northern India is swallowed by an epic smog cloud, critics say that Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s business-friendly policies are exacerbating the problem.
articles.abstract: As northern India is swallowed by an epic smog cloud, critics say that Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s business-friendly policies are exacerbating the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As millions of Indians watched a televised cricket match this week between the national teams of India and Sri Lanka, the game suddenly stopped.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Kai Schultz and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: Under New Tax Plan, the Cost of Aging Could Rise
articles.snippet: If the tax bill removes medical expense deductions, many people could lose over $10,000 annually.
articles.abstract: If the tax bill removes medical expense deductions, many people could lose over $10,000 annually.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the coming days, a small group of Republicans will meet in Washington to try to settle a simple question: Should their revised tax bill eliminate a deduction for medical expenses and take away thousands of dollars each year from many people who are sick and, often, old?

articles.headline: For Female Lobbyists, Harassment Often Accompanies Access
articles.snippet: In state legislatures, lobbyists whose jobs depend on access and influence are especially vulnerable to sexual harassment.
articles.abstract: In state legislatures, lobbyists whose jobs depend on access and influence are especially vulnerable to sexual harassment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vanessa Alarid was a lobbyist in New Mexico when she asked a lawmaker over drinks one night if she could count on his support for a bill that appeared to be coming down to a single vote.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Trent Franks, Accused of Offering $5 Million to Aide for Surrogacy, Resigns
articles.snippet: Mr. Franks, Republican of Arizona, resigned earlier than expected after two women said he wanted to use sex as a means to impregnate them.
articles.abstract: Mr. Franks, Republican of Arizona, resigned earlier than expected after two women said he wanted to use sex as a means to impregnate them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Trent Franks announced Friday that he would resign from Congress immediately after accusations emerged that he had offered $5 million to a female employee to be a surrogate mother for his children, and that she and another female employee worried that the lawmaker wanted to have sex as a means of impregnating them.

articles.headline: How the Fingerling Caught On (Robot Grip and All) as 2017’s Hot Toy
articles.snippet: The motorized plastic monkey that grasps your finger is the must-have gift of the holiday season, thanks to marketing, pricing and, well, scarcity.
articles.abstract: The motorized plastic monkey that grasps your finger is the must-have gift of the holiday season, thanks to marketing, pricing and, well, scarcity.
articles.lead_paragraph: About two years ago, Sydney Wiseman had a challenging assignment for an engineer at her family toy company.

articles.headline: Janet Yellen Didn’t Set Out to Be a Feminist Hero
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chair (don’t call her “chairwoman”) quietly achieved rock-star status. Now that she’s leaving, her many fans are sad to see her go.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chair (don’t call her “chairwoman”) quietly achieved rock-star status. Now that she’s leaving, her many fans are sad to see her go.
articles.lead_paragraph: She has been called “a small lady with a large I.Q.” She has been mocked for wearing the same outfit to both her official White House nomination and her confirmation hearing. (“At least we know her mind won’t be preoccupied with haute couture,” a Washington gossip columnist wrote.) And when President Barack Obama once referred to Janet L. Yellen as “Mr. Yellen,” she didn’t bother correcting him.

articles.headline: Can Marriott Keep Starwood’s Culture of Cool, and Its Customers?
articles.snippet: For the Marriott-Starwood combination to succeed, top-tier loyalty program members like our writer must not flee. Here’s what would keep him in the fold.
articles.abstract: For the Marriott-Starwood combination to succeed, top-tier loyalty program members like our writer must not flee. Here’s what would keep him in the fold.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Consider the conundrum of the modern hotel-room shopper.

articles.headline: Inside Trump’s Hour-by-Hour Battle for Self-Preservation
articles.snippet: With Twitter as his Excalibur, the president takes on his doubters, powered by long spells of cable news and a dozen Diet Cokes. But if Mr. Trump has yet to bend the presidency to his will, he is at least wrestling it to a draw.
articles.abstract: With Twitter as his Excalibur, the president takes on his doubters, powered by long spells of cable news and a dozen Diet Cokes. But if Mr. Trump has yet to bend the presidency to his will, he is at least wrestling it to a draw.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Around 5:30 each morning, President Trump wakes and tunes into the television in the White House’s master bedroom. He flips to CNN for news, moves to “Fox & Friends” for comfort and messaging ideas, and sometimes watches MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” because, friends suspect, it fires him up for the day.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Glenn Thrush and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Tax Plans May Give Your Co-Worker a Better Deal Than You
articles.snippet: The G.O.P. bills impose different rates on the same income based on things like organizational structure or occupation. At the losing end? Employees with paychecks.
articles.abstract: The G.O.P. bills impose different rates on the same income based on things like organizational structure or occupation. At the losing end? Employees with paychecks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In most places, a dollar is a dollar. But in the tax code envisioned by Republicans, the amount you make may be less important than how you make it.

articles.headline: Jerusalem: It’s Tense, Crowded and Can Feel Like a Jail
articles.snippet: For residents of Jerusalem, over which the world has been battling for thousands of years, everyday frictions can be draining on both sides of the Green Line.
articles.abstract: For residents of Jerusalem, over which the world has been battling for thousands of years, everyday frictions can be draining on both sides of the Green Line.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — This is a tense city on a good day.

articles.headline: With 2020 Census Looming, Worries About Fairness and Accuracy
articles.snippet: Census officials, scrapping mail-in forms for an online count, need money and the public’s trust to get an accurate head count. They’re short of both.
articles.abstract: Census officials, scrapping mail-in forms for an online count, need money and the public’s trust to get an accurate head count. They’re short of both.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Census experts and public officials are expressing growing concerns that the bedrock mission of the 2020 census — an accurate and trustworthy head count of everyone in the United States — is imperiled, with worrisome implications.

articles.headline: Under Trump, E.P.A. Has Slowed Actions Against Polluters, and Put Limits on Enforcement Officers
articles.snippet: An analysis of enforcement data at the E.P.A. shows a substantial drop in activity against polluters when compared with the Obama and Bush administrations.
articles.abstract: An analysis of enforcement data at the E.P.A. shows a substantial drop in activity against polluters when compared with the Obama and Bush administrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio — The highway billboard at the entrance to town still displays a giant campaign photograph of President Trump, who handily won the election across industrial Ohio. But a revolt is brewing here in East Liverpool over Mr. Trump’s move to slow down the federal government’s policing of air and water pollution.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Liberal Outsiders Pour Into Alabama Senate Race, Treading Lightly
articles.snippet: With only hours until the polls open in the unlikeliest of battleground states, Democrats are deploying a multimillion-dollar get-out-the-vote operation in an effort to steal away a Senate seat.
articles.abstract: With only hours until the polls open in the unlikeliest of battleground states, Democrats are deploying a multimillion-dollar get-out-the-vote operation in an effort to steal away a Senate seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — In the poinsettia-trimmed pulpit of Ebenezer Missionary Baptist Church on Sunday morning, the Rev. James Perkins Jr., the first black mayor of a city where the right to vote was won in blood, announced his support for the Democrat Doug Jones in Alabama’s special Senate election. He reminded his Selma congregants, without telling them how to vote, that sheep are to follow their shepherd.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: As Brexit Looms, Paris Tries a Business Makeover
articles.snippet: Hoping to woo companies that will move employees from London, leaders in Paris are trying to replace red tape with a red carpet.
articles.abstract: Hoping to woo companies that will move employees from London, leaders in Paris are trying to replace red tape with a red carpet.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The phone rings a lot at Paris Region Entreprises, a one-stop shop for companies deciding whether to move employees to the City of Light. Typically, callers ask about visas and minutiae of employment law. But not long ago, an executive from Japan called with a stumper: Where, he asked, are the dancing clubs?

articles.headline: Nikki Haley Says Women Who Accuse Trump of Misconduct ‘Should Be Heard’
articles.snippet: The comments by Ms. Haley, the United Nations ambassador, broke from the administration’s assertion that the allegations are false and voters rightly dismissed them.
articles.abstract: The comments by Ms. Haley, the United Nations ambassador, broke from the administration’s assertion that the allegations are false and voters rightly dismissed them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nikki R. Haley, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said on Sunday that women who have accused President Trump of sexual misconduct “should be heard,” a surprising break from the administration’s longstanding assertion that the allegations are false and that voters rightly dismissed them when they elected Mr. Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Once the W.T.O.’s Biggest Supporter, U.S. Is Its Biggest Skeptic
articles.snippet: The Trump administration isn’t alone in criticizing the World Trade Organization. But it may be the only country trying to subvert it.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration isn’t alone in criticizing the World Trade Organization. But it may be the only country trying to subvert it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As officials from the 164 countries in the World Trade Organization gather in Buenos Aires this week for their first major meeting in two years, they will be watching to see whether the United States, once the group’s biggest advocate, is seeking to subvert it.

articles.headline: A Fed Rate Increase Is Expected. But What Comes Next?
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve has signaled its move this week. Investors, though, want to know whether the central bank will continue with its patient approach to rates.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve has signaled its move this week. Investors, though, want to know whether the central bank will continue with its patient approach to rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is expected to end the year by raising its benchmark interest rate for just the fifth time since the financial crisis, as it continues to slowly unwind its post-crisis stimulus campaign. But pressures are building that could prompt the Fed to start moving a little more quickly.

articles.headline: How ISIS Produced Its Cruel Arsenal on an Industrial Scale
articles.snippet: When the Islamic State seized territory in Iraq and Syria, it had the time and space to industrialize advanced weapons manufacturing. The results included explosive space heaters and chemical rockets.
articles.abstract: When the Islamic State seized territory in Iraq and Syria, it had the time and space to industrialize advanced weapons manufacturing. The results included explosive space heaters and chemical rockets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Late this spring, Iraqi forces fighting the Islamic State in Mosul discovered three unfired rocket-propelled grenades with an unusual feature — a heavy liquid sloshing inside their warheads. Tests later found that the warheads contained a crude blister agent resembling sulfur mustard, a banned chemical weapon intended to burn a victim’s skin and respiratory tract.
articles.byline: By John Ismay, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and C. J. Chivers

articles.headline: Net Neutrality’s Holes in Europe May Offer Peek at Future in U.S.
articles.snippet: Telecom operators have been pushing boundaries in Europe, where loopholes have left net neutrality regulations weaker than intended.
articles.abstract: Telecom operators have been pushing boundaries in Europe, where loopholes have left net neutrality regulations weaker than intended.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, Swedes got a tantalizing offer: If they subscribed to Sweden’s biggest telecom provider, Telia Company AB, they could have unlimited access on their mobile phones to Facebook, Spotify, Instagram and other blockbuster apps.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Kelly Ripa and Ryan Seacrest Specialize in Small Talk and Big Ratings
articles.snippet: The homey “Live With Kelly and Ryan” sticks to light banter even as its NBC rival, Megyn Kelly, takes on weightier matters.
articles.abstract: The homey “Live With Kelly and Ryan” sticks to light banter even as its NBC rival, Megyn Kelly, takes on weightier matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The producer Michael Gelman was here, in this bare-bones Manhattan television studio, back in the 1980s, when Regis Philbin and Kathie Lee Gifford were putting on a casual morning show for a local New York audience.

articles.headline: Lives at Risk Inside a Senior Complex in Puerto Rico With No Power
articles.snippet: Conditions at the largest housing project for low-income seniors on the hurricane-ravaged island illustrate a health crisis for the most vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Conditions at the largest housing project for low-income seniors on the hurricane-ravaged island illustrate a health crisis for the most vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Altagracia Rodriguez de Jesus woke up on a recent morning and cranked open the aluminum shutters along one wall of her small, eighth-floor apartment overlooking the capital.
